title: Why do people hate liberal arts and people who have Liberal Arts degrees? - Quora

response.answer_text: In my experience most people who have a bad attitude towards liberal arts degrees don’t have an accurate understanding of what the phrase means. The most common mistake is focusing on the “arts” in the phrase and deciding liberal arts colleges don’t offer majors in the sciences. The next most common is thinking the “liberal” in liberal arts is related to the idea being a liberal in political views (the opposite of conservative, as in US politics).  Liberal arts is a term that predates both these narrow definitions (I’m not going to delve into the latin roots of these words, but you can find excellent articles on this online). The basic idea is that liberal arts is a phrase that represents the educational grounding across the variety of subjects needed for the citizen of a free society to thrive for the rest of their life. This generally means they will learn how to think clearly, breaking down arguments for both sides, communicate those arguments and conclusions well, and possess the interpersonal skills to work with other citizens to meet all the challenges life in a democracy such as the US might present.  The only people who actually hate liberal arts and liberal arts degrees are those who seek to oppress their citizens, whether through a dictatorship, totalitarianism, or other forms of society that have a vested interest in suppressing the fundamental human rights of their citizens to determine the course of their own lives. Everyone else who says they hate the liberal arts is, ipso facto, poorly educated.  That’s not to say that someone might also choose not to pursue this kind of education for very good reasons. It is a luxury for many people in the world who struggle to meet their basic needs and would be much better off with a trade-school or pre-professional education. Liberal arts colleges in the US wrestle with this idea and, as their endowments and fundraising permit, most make a very sincere effort to provide significant scholarship aid in order to not become a luxury good. Because a liberal arts education does tend to lead everyone involved to believe that our larger society is significantly harmed, both by the “have-nots” missing this opportunity and also by the “haves” learning in isolation.

In this day and age, I think people rather more pity them than hate them, but I understand the sentiment. By people, you must mean non-liberal arts majors - namely, engineers and “business” type majors, under whatever moniker. There are actually a few things going on here, in my observation. Classically speaking, being “educated” meant an education in the liberal arts - education (a luxury enjoyed by the wealthy) being somewhat distinct from vocation (a necessity of the lower classes). Thus, understand, for the vast majority of academe’s history, the condescension has been reversed: if you did not have an liberal arts education, you did not have an education, as it were; at best, you had a trade - such as building bridges … or blacksmithing. Within academe things have actually changed little culturally. The philosophy professor is substantially more ‘legitimate’ in his field than the ‘business’ professor - the latter being a very recent notion in terms of “education”, the former existing from antiquity. In the current/modern era, the prevailing notion is that a good “education” should translate directly to a good job - otherwise, why get one? A down-side of mixing apples and oranges - of converging the liberal arts with trades - is the risk that one ever mistakes itself for the other, producing a mish-mash that is really neither: nebulous “skills” that have little marketable utility, and an underwhelming survey of leading opinions bearing little long term value as “knowledge”. Few appreciate how new this association actually is, and how - in converging “the trades” with “the arts” - we have mixed apples and oranges.
